segment.source: WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM)
segment.target: WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM)

segment.source: WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM)
segment.target: WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM)

segment.source: WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM)
segment.target: WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM)

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) is a minimal operating system where you can prepare a PC for installation, deployment, and servicing of Windows.
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) is a minimal operating system where you can prepare a PC for installation, deployment, and servicing of Windows.

segment.source: Here's how to download and install it to an internal or external hard drive.
segment.target: Here's how to download and install it to an internal or external hard drive.

segment.source: These instructions show how to set up a basic Windows PE installation that runs from the drive.
segment.target: These instructions show how to set up a basic Windows PE installation that runs from the drive.

segment.source: This can sometimes give you better performance than booting from memory, and can help you run Windows PE on PCs or virtual environments with low memory.
segment.target: This can sometimes give you better performance than booting from memory, and can help you run Windows PE on PCs or virtual environments with low memory.

segment.source: This procedure is also known as a non-RAMDISK boot, or a flat boot.
segment.target: This procedure is also known as a non-RAMDISK boot, or a flat boot.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: When Windows PE is running from the drive, you must turn off the PC before disconnecting the drive to avoid losing your work.
segment.target: When Windows PE is running from the drive, you must turn off the PC before disconnecting the drive to avoid losing your work.

segment.source: Install the Windows ADK
segment.target: Install the Windows ADK

segment.source: Get the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) Technical Reference, including the Windows PE feature.
segment.target: Get the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) Technical Reference, including the Windows PE feature.

segment.source: Create a Set of Either 32-bit or 64-bit Windows PE Files
segment.target: Create a Set of Either 32-bit or 64-bit Windows PE Files

segment.source: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: In the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, copy the Windows PE files for the PCs you want to boot.
segment.target: In the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, copy the Windows PE files for the PCs you want to boot.

segment.source: The 64-bit version of Windows PE can boot 64-bit UEFI and 64-bit BIOS PCs:
segment.target: The 64-bit version of Windows PE can boot 64-bit UEFI and 64-bit BIOS PCs:

segment.source: The 32-bit version of Windows PE can boot 32-bit UEFI, 32-bit BIOS, and 64-bit BIOS PCs:
segment.target: The 32-bit version of Windows PE can boot 32-bit UEFI, 32-bit BIOS, and 64-bit BIOS PCs:

segment.source: Create a Working Directory for Windows PE Files
segment.target: Create a Working Directory for Windows PE Files

segment.source: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: From the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, create a working directory for the Windows PE files.
segment.target: From the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, create a working directory for the Windows PE files.

segment.source: Install Windows PE to the Media
segment.target: Install Windows PE to the Media

segment.source: Use DiskPart to prepare the partitions.
segment.target: Use DiskPart to prepare the partitions.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The following commands prepare a USB hard drive that can boot on either a BIOS-based or UEFI-based PC.
segment.target: The following commands prepare a USB hard drive that can boot on either a BIOS-based or UEFI-based PC.

segment.source: On UEFI-based PCs, Windows PE requires a boot partition formatted using the FAT32 file format, which only supports file sizes up to 4 GB.
segment.target: On UEFI-based PCs, Windows PE requires a boot partition formatted using the FAT32 file format, which only supports file sizes up to 4 GB.

segment.source: We recommend creating a separate partition on the drive, formatted using NTFS, so that you can store Windows images and other large files.
segment.target: We recommend creating a separate partition on the drive, formatted using NTFS, so that you can store Windows images and other large files.

segment.source: where disk number is the listed number of the external USB hard drive.
segment.target: where disk number is the listed number of the external USB hard drive.

segment.source: Apply the Windows PE image to the hard drive.
segment.target: Apply the Windows PE image to the hard drive.

segment.source: Set up the boot files.
segment.target: Set up the boot files.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Ignore any warning messages that say "Warning: Resume application not found."
segment.target: Ignore any warning messages that say "Warning: Resume application not found."

segment.source: Boot to Windows PE
segment.target: Boot to Windows PE

segment.source: Connect the device (internal or external USB hard drive) into the PC you want to work on.
segment.target: Connect the device (internal or external USB hard drive) into the PC you want to work on.

segment.source: Turn on the PC, and use the boot menus to select the Windows PE drive.
segment.target: Turn on the PC, and use the boot menus to select the Windows PE drive.

segment.source: Typically this requires pressing a hardware button or a key, such as the Esc key.
segment.target: Typically this requires pressing a hardware button or a key, such as the Esc key.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For UEFI-based PCs, you might need to find an option to manually select the UEFI boot files, for example, USBDrive01EFIBOOTBOOTX64.EFI.
segment.target: For UEFI-based PCs, you might need to find an option to manually select the UEFI boot files, for example, USBDrive01EFIBOOTBOOTX64.EFI.

segment.source: Windows PE starts automatically.
segment.target: Windows PE starts automatically.

segment.source: After the command window appears, the wpeinit command runs automatically.
segment.target: After the command window appears, the wpeinit command runs automatically.

segment.source: This might take a few minutes.
segment.target: This might take a few minutes.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: If the PC does not boot, try the following steps in sequence, and try to boot the PC after each step:
segment.target: If the PC does not boot, try the following steps in sequence, and try to boot the PC after each step:

segment.source: For external USB drives, try inserting the drive into a different USB port.
segment.target: For external USB drives, try inserting the drive into a different USB port.

segment.source: Avoid using USB hubs or cables, because they might not be detected during the boot sequence.
segment.target: Avoid using USB hubs or cables, because they might not be detected during the boot sequence.

segment.source: Avoid USB 3.0 ports if the firmware does not contain native support for USB 3.0.
segment.target: Avoid USB 3.0 ports if the firmware does not contain native support for USB 3.0.

segment.source: If your PC requires drivers to boot, such as storage drivers or video drivers, or if your driver requires changes to the registry, add the driver to the Windows PE image.
segment.target: If your PC requires drivers to boot, such as storage drivers or video drivers, or if your driver requires changes to the registry, add the driver to the Windows PE image.

segment.source: For more info, see WinPE: Mount and Customize.
segment.target: For more info, see WinPE: Mount and Customize.

segment.source: Update the firmware of the PC to the latest version.
segment.target: Update the firmware of the PC to the latest version.

segment.source: For tips on connecting to a network, see WinPE Network Drivers: Initializing and adding drivers.
segment.target: For tips on connecting to a network, see WinPE Network Drivers: Initializing and adding drivers.

segment.source: Running Windows Setup from Windows PE
segment.target: Running Windows Setup from Windows PE

segment.source: See Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments for tips on installing Windows on UEFI PCs that support both UEFI and legacy BIOS firmware modes, and for using the 32-bit (x86) version of Windows PE to install a 64-bit version of Windows.
segment.target: See Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments for tips on installing Windows on UEFI PCs that support both UEFI and legacy BIOS firmware modes, and for using the 32-bit (x86) version of Windows PE to install a 64-bit version of Windows.
